title: What is the difference between literal and figurative language? - Quora

response.answer_text: Literal language is meant to be taken (that is, understood) exactly as said. “Bob and Roger are playing poker in the kitchen” is literal language. It refers to two literal people (Bob and Roger) in a literal location (the kitchen) doing a literal thing (playing a particular type of card game). Figurative language is meant to exress some other concept by using metaphorical wording. “Bob is eating Roger’s lunch!” is figurative language (assuming that Bob is not actually eating from Roger’s plate). Instead, it means the Bob is winning against Roger in their poker game, by quite a margin. To determine the difference, one uses context and common sense. “The autumn wind took the leaves from the neighbor’s tree and dumped them all over my yard” makes sense in literal terms (other than possibly picturing the wind as a thinking force), and there seems no reason to try to interpret this as anything other than literal. “The autumn wind took me away to Thanksgivings of years past” is figurative. It makes little sense to suppose that wind could cause time-travel. But the feel of, and the sounds and smells carried by, the wind in autumn can induce a person’s memory centers to reflect on past events. So there is no reason to interpret this as anything other than a figurative way of saying that breezy autumn afternoons make me feel nostalgic.
Figurative language is abstract and not directly linked to the observable world. Literal language is concrete and usually linked to the observable world.
